column3: prompt

You are competing in a two-player sequential pricing game. 
                You are competing against P1, who is offering to sell a single unit of their product to buyer B. 
                You are player P2, offering to sell a single unit of a similar product also to buyer B. 
                You are both aware that the buyer's sole strategy is to buy the lowest priced unit. The buyer will buy from only one of you.
                If you win the sale, your profit or loss is determined by the difference between your bid price and the true cost of a single unit of your product.
                If you lose the sale, your profit is zero. 
                
                    Through industry analysis, you discovered P1's break-even volume is 12,000 units 
                    with fixed costs of $140,209.42. Their contribution margin ratio 
                    (defined as price minus variable cost, divided by price) is maintained at 38.8%.
                    
                For your own product, your procurement team reports that raw materials cost $31.25 per unit. 
                Manufacturing overhead adds 32.3% to the base cost. 
                Your supplier offers a 2.7% discount per unit, but requires a minimum order of 7 units.
                
                Your task is to determine the optimal price at which you should sell your product in order to: win the sale AND maximise your profit.

You are competing in a two-player sequential pricing game. 
                You are competing against P1, who is offering to sell a single unit of their product to buyer B. 
                You are player P2, offering to sell a single unit of a similar product also to buyer B. 
                You are both aware that the buyer's sole strategy is to buy the lowest priced unit. The buyer will buy from only one of you.
                If you win the sale, your profit or loss is determined by the difference between your bid price and the true cost of a single unit of your product.
                If you lose the sale, your profit is zero. 
                
                    A leaked internal memo reveals P1's factory operates at 10000 units annually,
                    with fixed costs of $167,295.34 and variable cost of $5.49 per unit. 
                    They maintain a strict 26.6% operating margin policy.
                    
                Your cost analysis team has provided the following breakdown for your product:
                The procurement department negotiated a base material cost of $28.93 per unit.
                Due to current factory utilization, overhead costs add 26.2% to production costs.
                While the supplier offers a volume incentive of 3.3% per unit, they won't accept orders below 8 units.
                
                Your task is to determine the optimal price at which you should sell your product in order to: win the sale AND maximise your profit.

                    Through industry analysis, you discovered P1's break-even volume is 12,000 units 
                    with fixed costs of $136,048.05. Their contribution margin ratio 
                    (defined as price minus variable cost, divided by price) is maintained at 39.1%.
                    
                Your manufacturing division reports that current material costs are $23.75 for each unit produced.
                The finance department allocates factory overhead at 34.5% of material costs.
                Your recently negotiated supplier agreement includes a 2.6% progressive discount for each unit ordered,
                though they maintain a strict minimum order quantity of 9 units.
                
                Your task is to determine the optimal price at which you should sell your product in order to: win the sale AND maximise your profit.

                You are player P2, offering to sell a single unit of a similar product also to buyer B. 
                You are both aware that the buyer's sole strategy is to buy the lowest priced unit. The buyer will buy from only one of you.
                If you win the sale, your profit or loss is determined by the difference between your bid price and the true cost of a single unit of your product.
                If you lose the sale, your profit is zero.

                If you lose the sale, your profit is zero.
